item.title: Chi-square distribution and hypothesis testing using Chi-statistic
item.description: 1. What is Chi-square? Assume that we observe an example of a categorical variable that has N different values, 1 through N. Each value has an expected (theoretical) frequency and an observed frequency. We can display them as the following table: value 1 value 2 … value N Observed frequency O_1 O_2 … O_N expected frequency E_1 E_2 … E_N Chi-Square is the sum of the squared difference between the observed and expected frequency divided by the number of values of the variable: $$\chi^2 = \sum^{N}_{j=1} \frac{(O_j - E_j)^2}{E_j}$$ 2.

item.title: Student's t-distribution and Confidence intervals using t-score
item.description: What is the T-distribution? T-distribution is known as the Student distribution. T-distribution allows for use of small samples (n < 30) with an unknown standard deviation of population, however it does so by sacrificing certainty with a margin-of-error trade-off. It also has a bell-shaped distribution as normal distribution and it converges into a normal distribution when sample size n is high. Probability density function: $$ f(t) = \frac {\varGamma(\frac{v+1}{2})}{\sqrt{v\pi}\varGamma(\frac{v}{2})} (1+\frac{t^2}{v})^{-\frac{v+1}{2}}$$ Where $$\varGamma$$ is the gamma function, and v = n-1 is the number of degrees of freedom.
